G.L. c. 218, \u00a73.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §3, as this action concerns a tenancy in Boston and the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limits of the Housing Court.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a719C.proposition: Venue is proper in the Boston Housing Court Department under G.L. c. 218, §19C, because the property that is the subject of this action is located within the court’s territorial jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, §14, a landlord shall not directly or indirectly interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a78A.proposition: Defendant had a duty to maintain the Premises in a condition fit for human habitation, as established by G.L. c. 239, §8A, G.L. c. 111, §§127A–127H, and the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et seq., which require that heating facilities be capable of maintaining at least 68°F from 7:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. and 64°F at night during the heating season.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7127A\u2013127H.proposition: Defendant had a duty to maintain the Premises in a condition fit for human habitation, as established by G.L. c. 239, §8A, G.L. c. 111, §§127A–127H, and the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et seq., which require that heating facilities be capable of maintaining at least 68°F from 7:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. and 64°F at night during the heating season.

105 CMR 410.000 et seq..proposition: Defendant had a duty to maintain the Premises in a condition fit for human habitation, as established by G.L. c. 239, §8A, G.L. c. 111, §§127A–127H, and the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et seq., which require that heating facilities be capable of maintaining at least 68°F from 7:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. and 64°F at night during the heating season.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (landlord’s failure to correct conditions creating substantial interference constitutes violation of G.L. c. 186, §14).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court expressly construes G.L. c. 186, § 14’s ‘quiet enjoyment’ clause to cover at least reckless failures by a landlord to maintain sanitary conditions, and holds Gem liable under § 14 because it violated its duty to maintain the premises, allowing repeated flooding that substantially interfered with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. This squarely supports the idea that a landlord’s failure to correct conditions causing substantial interference with the tenancy constitutes a violation of § 14, without requiring proof of specific intent to interfere.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “In sum, we hold that a tenant need not seek a criminal conviction before claiming damages under G. L. c. 186, § 14. Nor must the tenant prove that the landlord intended to interfere with the tenant’s rights, at least as long as the landlord’s conduct was reckless. Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977) (quiet enjoyment breached when landlord’s conduct indirectly prevented tenant’s beneficial use and enjoyment).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The court held that the landlords breached the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment and that constructive eviction occurred, even though the landlords did not intend to deprive the tenants of their enjoyment. The breach flowed as the “natural and probable consequence” of the landlords’ leasing nearby premises as a lounge and failing to control the resulting noise, which indirectly but substantially deprived the tenants of the beneficial use and enjoyment of their apartments. This aligns with the proposition that quiet enjoyment is breached when the landlord’s conduct indirectly prevents beneficial use and enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment includes the landlord’s obligation to ensure that vital services such as heat are maintained.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The case does discuss the covenant of quiet enjoyment but in the context of security and criminal activity in common areas, not vital services like heat. The court’s treatment of ‘vital facilities’ and services such as heat appears in its separate analysis of the implied warranty of habitability, not in its discussion of quiet enjoyment. The quiet enjoyment holding focuses on serious interference from the landlord’s failure to act against drug activity, not an obligation to maintain essential services, so it does not support the specific proposition about heat or other vital services under the quiet enjoyment covenant.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … [I]f the defendant has failed to take any measures… to remove unwelcome persons… then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).proposition: Defendant’s failure to remedy the heating defect after notice constitutes willful or at least negligent interference.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).support_reasoning: The decision discusses landlord liability under the implied warranty of habitability, covenant of quiet enjoyment, negligence, retaliation, emotional distress, and Chapter 93A, but it does not frame the landlord’s failure to remedy heating defects after notice specifically as ‘willful or at least negligent interference.’ The opinion focuses on breach of habitability, emotional distress, and unfair/deceptive practices rather than characterizing the failure to repair heat as interference in the legal sense suggested. Thus, it does not directly support that particular proposition.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).relevant_excerpt: After his view, the judge made express findings. Among other defects, the judge found that: (1) there was no functioning heating system; ... The judge ordered Haddad to repair most of the defects by August 22, 1983. He also ordered Haddad to install a heating system by September 15, 1983, and to have the apartment treated by a professional exterminator.... In late August, 1983, an inspector reinspected the apartment... [and] found that virtually all of the defects identified by the judge remained unrepaired.

Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976.raw_text: Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976 (1985)
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976.proposition: A landlord’s knowledge of poor conditions and failure to act can warrant treble damages under G.L. c. 186, §14.
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976.support_reasoning: The opinion upholds treble damages, but only under G.L. c. 93A, § 9(3), based on wilful/knowing unfair practices and a bad-faith response to a c. 93A demand letter. The discussion of G.L. c. 186, § 14 is limited to noting that its violation also constituted a c. 93A violation; the court does not state or imply that knowledge of poor conditions and failure to act, under § 14 itself, warrants treble damages. Thus the case is authority for enhanced damages under c. 93A, not for treble damages directly under c. 186, § 14.
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976.relevant_excerpt: “Damages were awarded under G. L. c. 93A, the judge concluding that his findings of negligence and of breach of the implied warranty of habitability, and of G. L. c. 186, § 14, ‘also constitute a violation of G. L. c. 93A.’ The judge trebled the damages on the ground that Brown’s violations were ‘wilful and knowing.’ … Under G. L. c. 93A, § 9(3) … a successful plaintiff may be awarded ‘up to three but not less than two times [the actual damages]’….”}

Khim v. Johnson, 2010 Mass. App. Div. 23.raw_text: Khim v. Johnson, 2010 Mass. App. Div. 238
Khim v. Johnson, 2010 Mass. App. Div. 23.proposition: The tenant’s use of alternative heat sources and continuing residence do not waive the right to claim breach.
Khim v. Johnson, 2010 Mass. App. Div. 23.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with procedural error in dismissing a complaint and imposing sanctions at a case management conference, focusing on Rule 12(b)(6), Rule 56 conversion, and lack of notice. It does not involve a landlord-tenant relationship, habitability, heat, or waiver by continued residence or use of alternative heat sources. Therefore, it does not address, much less support, the proposition about a tenant’s rights in those circumstances.
Khim v. Johnson, 2010 Mass. App. Div. 23.relevant_excerpt: What we do and must conclude is that it was beyond the scope of a case management conference for the trial court to consider matters of the credibility and weight of evidence. Both the dismissal of the complaint and the order imposing sanctions were error.

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: The covenant protects against conditions making the premises unfit for ordinary enjoyment.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that failure to provide heat, a basic service, breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it frames the breach in terms of “seriously impair[ing] the character and value of the leased premises,” not expressly as making them unfit for ordinary enjoyment. Nonetheless, the reasoning that lack of heat during the heating season is a serious impairment that triggers quiet enjoyment liability is consistent with the broader proposition that the covenant protects against conditions rendering premises unfit for ordinary enjoyment.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season… seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’… and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”
